p: Combined with the findings from our previous studies [ 29, 32], we propose that in a mixed biofilm, the C. albicans polysaccharide matrix, the increase in S. aureus matrix components, and interactions via secreted chemical moleucles, create a protective environment advantageous to S. aureus ( Figure 7). Therefore, the work presented provides novel mechanistic insights into interspecies interactions in biofilms, with important clinical relevance. We expect the novel findings from this study to further our understanding of the enhanced pathogenesis and resistance of biofilm-associated polymicrobial infections, which may contribute to the development of novel therapeutic strategies targeting these complex infections.
